title: Febrile Seizure (Child)
summary: Seizures in young children caused by rapid temperature rise. Frightening but usually harmless. Stay calm and protect child from injury.

steps.title: Stay Calm and Time Seizure
steps.description: Note time seizure starts. Most febrile seizures last 1-2 minutes. Stay calm - your child needs you composed. Do not restrain child or put anything in mouth. Clear area of hard objects.

steps.title: Position Child Safely
steps.description: Place child on soft surface (bed, carpet) on their side. This prevents choking on saliva. Loosen tight clothing around neck. Do not try to stop movements. Stay with child.

steps.title: Call for Help if Needed
steps.description: Call 911 if: first seizure, lasts over 5 minutes, child has breathing problems, repeated seizures, or you're concerned. Most febrile seizures don't require emergency care but first ones should be evaluated.

steps.title: After Seizure Care
steps.description: Child may be sleepy or confused. Keep on side until fully awake. Check temperature. Remove extra clothing to help cool. Comfort and reassure - child won't remember seizure.

steps.title: Reduce Fever
steps.description: Give age-appropriate dose of acetaminophen or ibuprofen when child is alert. Lukewarm sponge bath may help. Do NOT use cold water or alcohol. See doctor even if child seems fine.

warnings: Never leave child alone during or immediately after seizure
Do not give fever medicine during seizure - wait until after
Febrile seizures don't cause brain damage but need medical evaluation
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 for first febrile seizure or if lasting over 5 minutes
See doctor same day for all febrile seizures
Call 911 if child has difficulty breathing or multiple seizures
preventionTips: Treat fevers promptly in children prone to febrile seizures
Know family history - febrile seizures can run in families
Keep fever reducers at appropriate doses on hand
